Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: They fill a high-risk chemotherapy prescription where even a small error could have severe consequences for the patient.
Story: I was in the pharmacy, double-checking the dosage on a high-risk chemotherapy prescription. My hands were steady, but my mind was focused—one small error could mean disaster for the patient. Just then, my phone buzzed. It was my friend, Sarah, who had just moved into her new apartment. She sounded frazzled in her message, asking if I could hop on a quick video call to help her figure out the confusing furniture instructions. She’d always been there for me, and I knew she was counting on me now, probably surrounded by scattered screws and half-built shelves. But the prescription in front of me demanded my full attention; the patient’s safety depended on it. I felt torn, the weight of both responsibilities pressing down on me. My friend needed me, but so did my patient. I stared at my phone, heart pounding, caught between the urge to help Sarah and the duty to ensure every detail of the medication was perfect.
